Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Diwali / Deepavali
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Diwali, the five-day Festival of Lights, celebrates the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil; families light oil lamps, exchange sweets, and set off fireworks in honor of Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth. (Source: BBC) :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Holi
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Holi, the Festival of Colours, marks the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil; celebrants throw colored powders and water, dance, and enjoy festive foods like gujiya. (Source: National Geographic) :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Navratri / Durga Puja / Dussehra
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Navratri is a nine-night festival honoring the divine feminine (Devi); in eastern India it culminates in Durga Puja with elaborate clay idols and pandals, while Dussehra (Vijayadashami) celebrates Rama’s victory over Ravana with effigy burnings. (Sources: UNESCO, CNN) :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Ganesh Chaturthi
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Ganesh Chaturthi honors the birth of Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom; families install clay idols at home or in public pandals and immerse them in water after 1–10 days, symbolizing his return to Mount Kailash. (Source: Smithsonian) :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Janmashtami
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Janmashtami celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna with fasting, night-long vigil, devotional singing, and dramatic reenactments of his childhood (Rasa Lila), culminating at midnight—the traditional hour of his birth. (Source: The Hindu) :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Ram Navami
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Ram Navami marks the birth of Lord Rama with readings of the Ramayana, processions bearing his idols, and devotional singing, especially in Ayodhya, his birthplace. (Source: Hindustan Times) :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Maha Shivaratri
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Maha Shivaratri, the Night of Shiva, is observed with all-night vigils, fasting, and offerings of bilva leaves at Shiva temples, symbolizing overcoming darkness and ignorance. (Source: Britannica) :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Raksha Bandhan
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Raksha Bandhan celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters; sisters tie a protective thread (rakhi) around their brothers’ wrists, and brothers give gifts in return, pledging to protect them. (Source: Times of India) :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Krishna Janmashtami
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: See Janmashtami above—the same festival marking Krishna’s birth, often celebrated with Dahi Handi events in Maharashtra, where teams form human pyramids to break a pot of curd hung high. (Source: Indian Express) :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Makar Sankranti
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Makar Sankranti marks the sun’s transit into Capricorn, signaling longer days; celebrated across India with kite flying (Gujarat), potluck feasts (Punjab), and harvesting rituals (Assam). (Source: The Guardian) :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Baisakhi
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Baisakhi, the Punjabi harvest festival and Sikh New Year, features vibrant bhangra dances, langar (community kitchens), and processions in gurudwaras celebrating the formation of the Khalsa. (Source: BBC) :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Pongal
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Pongal is a four-day Tamil harvest festival thanking the Sun god; families cook sweet rice (pongal) in new clay pots and decorate homes with kolam (rice-flour designs). (Source: The Hindu) :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

Pan-India “Major” Holidays.heading: Onam
Pan-India “Major” Holidays.brief: Onam, Kerala’s harvest festival, honors the mythical King Mahabali; celebrations include boat races, tiger dances, floral carpets (pookalam), and the grand Onam feast (sadya). (Source: National Geographic) :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Chhath Puja
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Chhath Puja venerates the Sun god with rigorous four-day rituals on riverbanks—holy dips, fasting, and offerings at dawn and dusk—to thank him for sustaining life. (Source: BBC) :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Bhagoriya / Gangaur
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Gangaur, celebrated in Rajasthan, honors Gauri (consort of Shiva) and is marked by colorful processions, folk songs, and the worship of clay idols of the goddess. (Source: Times of India) :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Bengali Ekadashi Observances
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: In Bengal, Ekadashi fasts (e.g., Jhulna Yatra) involve devotees swinging (jhulna) idols of Krishna and radha on specially constructed jhulas (swings). (Source: The Hindu) :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Chithirai Thiruvizha
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Madurai’s Chithirai Thiruvizha reenacts the celestial wedding of Meenakshi and Sundareswarar and the festival parade of Alagar to Vaigai river, drawing millions. (Source: UNESCO) :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Gudi Padwa
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Maharashtra’s New Year festival Gudi Padwa marks the sun’s entry into Aries; homes display gilded gudi flags and families exchange sweets. (Source: The Guardian) :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Ugadi
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Ugadi, Telugu and Kannada New Year, features special chutneys symbolizing life’s sour, sweet, and spicy moments, and readings of the Panchanga (almanac). (Source: National Geographic) :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Poila Boishakh
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Poila Boishakh, Bengali New Year, sees shops opening at “Halkhata” ceremonies, cultural programs, and families feasting on traditional sweets. (Source: The Hindu) :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Karthika Mahotsavam
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: In Kerala, Karthika Mahotsavam is a month-long festival of lamps at Sabarimala and Guruvayur temples, honoring Lord Ayyappa. (Source: Hindustan Times) :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Karni Mata Fair
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Held in Deshnoke, Rajasthan, this fair venerates Karni Mata at her rat temple, where thousands of black rats roam freely and devotees offer milk. (Source: BBC) :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}

Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.heading: Hampi Utsav
Regional or State-level Hindu Festivals.brief: Hampi Utsav, Karnataka’s heritage festival, showcases music, dance, and puppet shows amidst the ruins of the Vijayanagara Empire. (Source: UNESCO) :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Rath Yatra
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: An annual chariot festival held in Puri, Odisha, dedicated to Lord Jagannath, where three massive wooden chariots carrying the deities Jagannath, Balabhadra and Subhadra are pulled by thousands of devotees from the Jagannath Temple to the Gundicha Temple and back over the course of a week.

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Sabarimala Makara Vilakku
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: A sacred festival at the hill shrine of Sabarimala in Kerala during Makar Sankranti, marked by the Thiruvabharanam procession of Lord Ayyappa’s sacred ornaments and the appearance of a holy fire ('Makaravilakku') on Ponnambalamedu, drawing over half a million pilgrims each year.

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Tyagaraja Aradhana
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: An annual Carnatic music festival in Thiruvaiyaru, Tamil Nadu, commemorating the saint-composer Tyagaraja on the anniversary of his death, during which musicians from across South India gather to render his Pancharatna Kritis.

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Tirupati Brahmotsavam
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: A nine-day grand celebration at the Sri Venkateswara Temple in Tirumala–Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, featuring daily processions of the processional deity Malayappa Swami and his consorts on various vahanas (vehicles) through the streets around the temple.

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Vaikunta Ekadashi
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: The most important Vaishnavite festival at Tirumala in Andhra Pradesh, observed on the 11th day of the bright fortnight of the month of Margashirsha, when the special Vaikunta Dvaram gateway is opened and over 150,000 devotees pass through it to have darshan of Lord Venkateswara.

Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.heading: Chamundeshwari Puja
Temple-Centric or Deity-Centred Festival.brief: The chief ritual of Mysore Dasara in Karnataka, centered on the Chamundeshwari Temple atop Chamundi Hills, where the goddess Chamundeshwari (a form of Durga) is worshipped with elaborate offerings, processions and cultural performances during the ten-day festival.

Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.heading: Chhau Dance Festival
Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.brief: A cultural festival in Odisha, Jharkhand and West Bengal showcasing Chhau, a semi-classical masked dance form that blends martial movements and folk traditions rooted in tribal rituals.

Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.heading: Kherwal Bird Festival
Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.brief: Observed by the Kherwal (Santhal) community of Jharkhand on Poush Sankranti, this tribal observance involves offering prayers and food to birds in sacred groves, reflecting the community’s totemic reverence for avifauna and nature worship.

Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.heading: Mopin
Folk-Hindu or Tribal-Influenced Observan.brief: A harvest festival celebrated by the Galo tribe of Arunachal Pradesh in early April, dedicated to the goddess Mopin Ane, believed to bring wealth and prosperity, marked by traditional dances, feasts and community prayers for a bountiful crop.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Eid‑ul‑Fitr
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: Celebrated at the end of Ramadan, Eid‑ul‑Fitr involves communal prayers, charity (zakat al‑fitr), lavish meals, and social visits.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Eid‑ul‑Adha (Bakrid)
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: Marking Ibrahim’s willingness to sacrifice his son, Eid‑ul‑Adha includes animal sacrifice, meat distribution, prayers, and pilgrim reflections after Hajj.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Muharram / Ashura
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: The first month of the Islamic calendar; Ashura commemorates Imam Husayn’s martyrdom for Shias, and Sunni traditions include fasting.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Milad‑un‑Nabi (Mawlid)
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: Observance of Prophet Muhammad’s birthday, with recitations of his life, special prayers, charity, and communal meals.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Shab‑e‑Meras (Shab‑e‑Isra‑wa‑Miraj)
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: Remembers Prophet Muhammad’s night journey to heaven; marked with late-night prayers and Quran recitations.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Shab‑e‑Barat
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: The Night of Forgiveness—believed to determine fate for the next year; Muslims pray for forgiveness and visit graves.

Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.heading: Ramadan
Major Pan-India Islamic Holidays.brief: A month of fasting from dawn to sunset, special nightly Taraweeh prayers and reflection to commemorate the Quran’s first revelation.

Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.heading: Ajmer Urs
Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.brief: Annual death anniversary of Sufi saint Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti at Ajmer Sharif Dargah, attracting pilgrims across faiths.

Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.heading: Khambat Urs
Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.brief: Annual Urs of Sufi saint Qutbuddin Bakhtiar Khaki in Khambat (Gujarat), featuring devotional music and gatherings.

Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.heading: Basara Urs
Regional Islamic Commemorations or Urs F.brief: Honours local Sufi saints in Telangana; involves qawwali singing at shrines and communal meals.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Gurpurabs
Major Sikh Observances.brief: Anniversaries of Sikh Gurus’ births/deaths—especially Guru Nanak and Guru Gobind Singh—marked by processions, kirtan, and community kitchens.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Vaisakhi
Major Sikh Observances.brief: Baisakhi marks the formation of the Khalsa and Punjabi harvest; features vibrant processions, gurdwara services and bhangra.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Hola Mohalla
Major Sikh Observances.brief: Held after Holi in Anandpur Sahib; martial displays, mock battles, poetry and community meals showcase Sikh valor.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Maghi Mela
Major Sikh Observances.brief: In Muktsar, commemorates the 40 Sikh martyrs; devotees take dips and attend gurudwara services.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Parkash Utsav
Major Sikh Observances.brief: Day celebrating the installation of Guru Granth Sahib; includes akhand paths and devotional singing.

Major Sikh Observances.heading: Martyrdom Days
Major Sikh Observances.brief: Observed for Sahibzada Zorawar & Fateh Singh, and Guru Tegh Bahadur—marked by prayer and remembrance.

Regional Gurudwara Melas.heading: Anandpur Sahib Hola Mohalla
Regional Gurudwara Melas.brief: Large-scale martial arts & religious gathering with performances and langar, centred on Anandpur Sahib.

Regional Gurudwara Melas.heading: Ramgarhia Bunga Fair
Regional Gurudwara Melas.brief: Held at Amritsar’s Ramgarhia Bunga—features music, communal kitchens, religious readings, and community fellowship.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: Christmas
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: Celebrating Jesus Christ’s birth on December 25 with church services, carols, nativity displays, and festive meals.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: Good Friday / Easter Sunday
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: Commemorates Jesus’ crucifixion (Good Friday) and resurrection (Easter Sunday), with solemn services and choirs.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: Palm Sunday
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: Marks Jesus' entry into Jerusalem—processions with palm fronds at church entrances.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: Epiphany / Theophany
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: January 6 observance in some denominations, celebrating the visit of the Magi and the manifestation of Christ.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: Pentecost
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: Fiftieth day after Easter, commemorating the Holy Spirit’s descent; churches hold special prayers and hymns.

Pan-India Christian Observances.heading: All Saints’ Day / All Souls’ Day
Pan-India Christian Observances.brief: November 1–2 remembrance of saints and departed souls, with church services and prayers.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: Feast of St Francis Xavier
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: December 3 feast in Goa celebrating the missionary’s legacy; features church processions and Konkani hymns.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: Feast of St Thomas
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: July 3 celebration in Kerala recognizing Apostle Thomas’ arrival—marked with masses and pilgrimages.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: Saint Kuriakose Elias Chavara Feast
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: Kerala feast day honoring this 19th‑century Catholic reformer, celebrated with prayer and local events.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: Mount St Thomas Annual Pilgrimage
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: Pilgrimage in Kerala to Mount St. Thomas shrine, with masses and family gatherings.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: East Indian Community Feasts
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: Mumbai feasts celebrated by the local Catholic community—marked with processions, liturgies, and shared meals.

Regional or Denominational Celebrations.heading: Portuguese‑style Processions in Goa
Regional or Denominational Celebrations.brief: Traditional Good Friday Way of the Cross and Easter processions reflecting colonial-era liturgy and music.

Major Jain Observances.heading: Mahavir Jayanti
Major Jain Observances.brief: Celebrates the birth of Lord Mahavira, the 24th Tirthankara; observed with processions, temple rituals, and lectures on non-violence.

Major Jain Observances.heading: Paryushana / Das Lakshan Parva
Major Jain Observances.brief: Eight to ten-day period of fasting, repentance, scripture reading, and forgiveness rituals among Jains.

Major Jain Observances.heading: Diwali (Jain Parinirvana)
Major Jain Observances.brief: Marks Lord Mahavira’s liberation (nirvana); observed with temple lamps, scriptures, and reflection on spiritual liberation.

Major Jain Observances.heading: Kartik Purnima (Kshamavani)
Major Jain Observances.brief: Śvētāmbara forgiveness day—Jains ask forgiveness from all beings for offenses committed in the past year.

Major Jain Observances.heading: Ranakpur Mahotsav
Major Jain Observances.brief: Festival at Ranakpur’s Jain temples in Rajasthan featuring rituals, lights, music, and pilgrim visits.

Regional Jain Temple Festivals.heading: Shravanabelagola Mahamastakabhisheka
Regional Jain Temple Festivals.brief: Ritual bathing of the 57‑ft Gommateshwara statue in Karnataka, held every 12 years with devotees applying sacred powders.

Regional Jain Temple Festivals.heading: Shikharji Yatra
Regional Jain Temple Festivals.brief: Pilgrimage to Shikharji hills in Jharkhand—the most sacred Jain site—where devotees climb temples honoring liberated souls.

Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.heading: Buddha Purnima / Vesak
Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.brief: Commemorates Buddha’s birth, enlightenment, and nirvana with prayers, processions, and meditation at Buddhist temples.

Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.heading: Magha Puja
Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.brief: Also called Sangha Day—honors Buddha and his disciples with candlelit processions and teachings at temples like Sarnath.

Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.heading: Loy Krathong
Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.brief: Water lantern festival observed in Northeast India, where lighted floats are set adrift for purification.

Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.heading: Dhamma Chakra Pravartan Din
Pan-Buddhist Observances in India.brief: International Buddhist Day, celebrated at Sarnath where Buddha delivered his first discourse—includes sermons and ceremonies.

Region-Specific Celebrations.heading: Losar
Region-Specific Celebrations.brief: Tibetan New Year celebrated in Ladakh, Sikkim and Arunachal with prayers, dances, and family gatherings.

Region-Specific Celebrations.heading: Saga Dawa
Region-Specific Celebrations.brief: Tibetan observance of Buddha’s birth, enlightenment, and death—entails merit‑making like prostrations and lantern lighting.

Region-Specific Celebrations.heading: Ambedkar Jayanti
Region-Specific Celebrations.brief: On April 14, Neo-Buddhists honor Dr. B.R. Ambedkar’s conversion to Buddhism and social reform legacy.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Nowruz / Navroz
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Zoroastrian New Year celebrated on March 21 with house cleaning, prayers, Haft-Seen table, and festive meals.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Jamshedi Navroz
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Traditional Parsi New Year involving prayers at fire temples and gatherings with traditional food.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Khordad Sal
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Birth anniversary of Prophet Zarathustra celebrated with ritual prayers, donation, and community feasts.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Pateti
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Day before Navroz devoted to reflection and repentance for one’s past misdeeds.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Mehergan
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Autumn harvest festival with thanks to the sun, charity, and communal feasting.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Bahman Mahino
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: A fire-themed ancient celebration honoring spirits of fire with prayers at Atash Behrams.

Guinness-Recognized Observances.heading: Khordad Roj
Guinness-Recognized Observances.brief: Monthly religious celebration honoring creation and divine perfection.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Passover / Pesach
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Commemorates the Exodus from Egypt with seders, unleavened bread, and scriptural readings.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Yom Kippur
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Day of Atonement marked by 25-hour fast, repentance, and intensive synagogue prayer.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Rosh Hashanah
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Jewish New Year celebrated with shofar blowing, prayers, and festive meals.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Chanukah
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Festival of Lights with menorah lighting, dreidel games, and oil-based snacks over eight nights.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Purim
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Celebrates salvation of Jewish people in Persia—marked with reading the Megillah, costumes, and feasting.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Sukkot
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Feast of Booths; build and dwell in sukkah huts to commemorate the Exodus wandering.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Simchat Torah
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Joyful marking of Torah reading cycle completion with dancing and Torah processions.

Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.heading: Shavuot
Common Observances (in small Indian Jewi.brief: Festival of Weeks celebrating giving of Torah at Sinai; observed with dairy foods and all-night study.

Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.heading: Karam
Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.brief: Santals, Gonds, and others honor the Karam tree deity with offerings, dances and communal feasts.

Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.heading: Baha
Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.brief: Bodo flower festival in Assam celebrating spring with floral offerings and Bwisagu dances.

Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.heading: Mopin
Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.brief: Apatani prosperity festival in Arunachal featuring mask dances, livestock blessings and rice feasts.

Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.heading: Bhagoria Haat
Harvest-Based Tribal Festivals.brief: Bharia tribal wedding fair in Madhya Pradesh where youth meet and Pariyan dances occur.

Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.heading: Jhumur
Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.brief: Eastern tribal harvest dance festival with rhythmic group dances after harvest.

Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.heading: Phuh‑er Baisi
Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.brief: Naga pre-harvest festival involving ritual offerings of meat and rice to invoke bounty.

Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.heading: Kut Festival
Rain or Water-Related Ritual Festivals.brief: Mizoram thanksgiving for harvest in March/April featuring feasts and folk songs.

Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.heading: Tor‑Sangam
Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.brief: Arunachali ritual for the Singhpoo tribe venerating ancestral spirits through offerings.

Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.heading: Gundru
Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.brief: Khandeshi tribal worship in Maharashtra invoking local deities for health and fortune.

Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.heading: Aori Kol
Ancestral or Spirit-Worship Festivals.brief: Jharkhand tribal festival honoring nature deities with animal sacrifices and community meals.

Folk-Dance and Music Celebrations (Ritua.heading: Chhau Festival
Folk-Dance and Music Celebrations (Ritua.brief: Mask dance tradition of Odisha/Jharkhand blending martial movements and mythological themes.

Folk-Dance and Music Celebrations (Ritua.heading: Kalbelia Cultural Festival
Folk-Dance and Music Celebrations (Ritua.brief: Rajasthani snake-charmer community performs gyrating dances and folk songs.

Mid-Winter or January Festivals.heading: Lohri
Mid-Winter or January Festivals.brief: Celebrated in Punjab and North India, Lohri marks the end of winter with bonfires, folk songs, dances, and harvest offerings.

Mid-Winter or January Festivals.heading: Makar Sankranti
Mid-Winter or January Festivals.brief: Observed nationwide, it marks the sun's shift into Capricorn and is celebrated with kite-flying, sesame sweets, and harvest rituals.

Mid-Winter or January Festivals.heading: Pongal
Mid-Winter or January Festivals.brief: Tamil Nadu’s harvest festival thanking the Sun god with boiled sweet rice and traditional rituals over four days.

Spring Festivals (February–April).heading: Vasant Panchami
Spring Festivals (February–April).brief: Marks the onset of spring and is dedicated to Saraswati, the goddess of wisdom, with yellow clothing and feasts.

Spring Festivals (February–April).heading: Ugadi
Spring Festivals (February–April).brief: New Year festival in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Karnataka, celebrated with neem-jaggery chutney and Panchanga Shravanam.

Spring Festivals (February–April).heading: Gudi Padwa
Spring Festivals (February–April).brief: Maharashtra’s New Year festival with gudi flags, neem-based dishes, and prayers to mark spring.

Spring Festivals (February–April).heading: Baisakhi
Spring Festivals (February–April).brief: Sikh and Punjabi New Year, also marking wheat harvest, with fairs, bhangra, and gurdwara processions.

Summer Festivals (May–July).heading: Buddha Purnima
Summer Festivals (May–July).brief: Commemorates the Buddha’s birth, enlightenment, and death with prayers and acts of compassion.

Summer Festivals (May–July).heading: Saga Dawa
Summer Festivals (May–July).brief: Tibetan Buddhist festival honoring Buddha’s life events with lanterns, chants, and charity.

Summer Festivals (May–July).heading: Ambubachi Mela
Summer Festivals (May–July).brief: Held at Kamakhya Temple in Assam, marks the goddess's menstruation with temple closure, rituals, and tantric observances.

Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.heading: Teej
Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.brief: Observed by women in North India and Nepal with fasting and songs, praying for marital bliss and monsoon prosperity.

Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.heading: Raksha Bandhan
Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.brief: Sisters tie rakhi on brothers’ wrists symbolizing protection; celebrated during Shravan Purnima.

Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.heading: Onam
Monsoon and Late Summer Festivals (July–.brief: Kerala’s biggest festival with floral rangolis, snake boat races, and grand vegetarian feasts.

Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.heading: Navratri / Durga Puja
Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.brief: Nine nights of goddess worship with dance (Garba/Dandiya) and idol immersion rituals in Bengal and Gujarat.

Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.heading: Dussehra
Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.brief: Symbolizes the victory of Rama over Ravana and Durga over Mahishasura; celebrated with effigy burning and pageants.

Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.heading: Diwali
Autumn and Diwali Season (September–Nove.brief: Festival of Lights celebrated across India with diyas, fireworks, sweets, and prayers to Lakshmi.

Early Winter and Christmas Season (Novem.heading: Guru Nanak Jayanti
Early Winter and Christmas Season (Novem.brief: Birth of Guru Nanak celebrated with Prabhat Pheris, langars, and Akhand Path readings.

Early Winter and Christmas Season (Novem.heading: Christmas
Early Winter and Christmas Season (Novem.brief: Marks the birth of Jesus Christ with church services, nativity plays, carols, and festive meals.

North India (Group of States).heading: Lohri
North India (Group of States).brief: Celebrated in Punjab and Himachal Pradesh, Lohri marks winter’s end with bonfires, folk dances, and songs.
